body: @cupermanrose Where are you confused with? This is my qq number:876814711,we can talk on QQ.

I observed the same problem. 

I have a computer with 12 cores from 2 CPUs. When I run mxnet, the CPU usage is only about 10%, which does not change no matter how I setup MXNET_CPU_WORKER_NTHREADS and OPENBLAS_NUM_THREADS.
You need to change your eval_metric from 'acc' to 'MAE', 'MSE', or 'RMSE' if you're using the Python package.
I don't have an example at hand. If you can't understand the doc, try reading the code in mxnet/initializer.py:Mixed

I just read the code in `initializer.py`. And it makes no sense to me that the base `Initializer` class would process 'bias', 'gamma', 'weights' etc one by one. It's a ridiculous design.

An initializer should be responsible for initializing **one and any one variable**. And it's users responsibility to determine which variable this initializer will init. 

With the current design, the `Uniform` initializer should be called `UniformWeight` because it can't be used on bias or any other variables. And users will have to write another 'UniformBias' initializer if they need, which has almost duplicated code.

Apart from code reusability, maintainer will have to add a new line in `Initializer` whenever there is a new variable defined in some new layer, to provide a default initialization behavior.

Tensorflow, for example, does a better job where you can specify how to initialize the variable at variable definition time. In this way default initialization can then be built into layers.

BTW @Gelu74 there is a bug in `mx.init.Mixed` which affects python3. If you use python3, you might want to wait for #1361 to be merged.
Thanks a lot@jmschrei. But how to change the eval_metric?

@ppwwyyxx The problem with building init into layers is that you'll have to write init code in C++ and it becomes harder to write and change.
If init stays in the front end, your solution basically means the default initializer is a Mixed initializer that dispatch based on name. It's mostly the same deal.

copy config.mk under root directory(~/mxnet). this is my config.mk.

#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Template configuration for compiling mxnet

#

# If you want to change the configuration, please use the following

# steps. Assume you are on the root directory of mxnet. First copy the this

# file so that any local changes will be ignored by git

#

# $ cp make/config.mk .

#

# Next modify the according entries, and then compile by

#

# $ make

#

# or build in parallel with 8 threads

#

# $ make -j8

#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

#---------------------

# choice of compiler

#--------------------

export CC = gcc
export CXX = g++
export NVCC = nvcc

# whether compile with debug

DEBUG = 0

# the additional link flags you want to add

ADD_LDFLAGS =

# the additional compile flags you want to add

ADD_CFLAGS =

#---------------------------------------------

# matrix computation libraries for CPU/GPU

#---------------------------------------------

# whether use CUDA during compile

USE_CUDA = 1

# add the path to CUDA libary to link and compile flag

# if you have already add them to enviroment variable, leave it as NONE

USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda
#USE_CUDA_PATH = NONE

# whether use CUDNN R3 library

USE_CUDNN = 1

# whether use cuda runtime compiling for writing kernels in native language

(i.e. Python)
USE_NVRTC = 0

# whether use opencv during compilation

# you can disable it, however, you will not able to use

# imbin iterator

USE_OPENCV = 1

# use openmp for parallelization

USE_OPENMP = 1

# choose the version of blas you want to use

# can be: mkl, blas, atlas, openblas

# in default use atlas for linux while apple for osx

UNAME_S := $(shell uname -s)
ifeq ($(UNAME_S), Darwin)
USE_BLAS = apple
else
USE_BLAS = mkl
endif

# add path to intel libary, you may need it for MKL, if you did not add the

path

# to enviroment variable

USE_INTEL_PATH = /opt/intel

# If use MKL, choose static link automaticly to allow python wrapper

ifeq ($(USE_BLAS), mkl)
USE_STATIC_MKL = 1
else
USE_STATIC_MKL = NONE
endif

#----------------------------

# distributed computing

#----------------------------

# whether or not to enable mullti-machine supporting

USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 0

# whether or not allow to read and write HDFS directly. If yes, then hadoop

is

# required

USE_HDFS = 0

# path to libjvm.so. required if USE_HDFS=1

LIBJVM=$(JAVA_HOME)/jre/lib/amd64/server

# whether or not allow to read and write AWS S3 directly. If yes, then

# libcurl4-openssl-dev is required, it can be installed on Ubuntu by

# sudo apt-get install -y libcurl4-openssl-dev

USE_S3 = 0

#----------------------------

# additional operators

#----------------------------

# path to folders containing projects specific operators that you don't

want to put in src/operators
EXTRA_OPERATORS =

By 'bulit into layers' I didn't mean built into operators. I'm assuming there is a layer-like abstraction such as the `ConvFactory` in imagenet examples. And if initialization method of a variable can be given in variable definition time (like in TensorFlow), a layer abstraction will then be able to provide default initialization. But I guess this will introduce too many changes to the current system.
Sorry that I might be unclear about the opinion. I think there are two issues with the current design that are worth a discussion:
- The initializers in the code right now are parameter-specific: `Uniform` is actually `UniformWeight` initializer. The alternative is to have an initializer available to use with any parameters, and let users choose explicitly, for example, like:

``` python
mx.init.Mixed(['.*_weight', '.*'], [mx.init.Uniform(),SomeDefaultInitializer()])
```

The advantage is to have reusable code for the implementation of initializer, especially when parameters with new names are created.
- The author of a layer abstraction (such as `ConvFactory`) cannot suggest its users a default initializer. Therefore if a new layer abstraction, or simply some new parameters in the graph with un-recognized names are created, either the source code of `Initializer` base class has to be modified to recognize the name and perform default initializer, or a user must explicitly give this default initilaizer through mx.init.Mixed before he starts training. 
  I think neither of "maintaining a list of names in the source code" or  "having users to write code to get default behavior", is a good idea.

Thanks
If you're using python, add `eval_metric='rmse'` to the fit method.

I don't like the current name based approach either but it hasn't caused enough trouble to compel action. If you have concrete thoughts you are welcome to propose a PR and we can have more discussion.

I suggest starting with breaking down base Initializer class into separate "pure" initializers and refactor specialized initializers to be subclass of Mixed Initializer.
Building init into layer abstraction is harder because layers are registered in C++. The corresponding python code is automatically generated. So it's hard to do layer specific things in the front end. It might be possible to use symbol attributes for this.

Thanks a lot! I think this makes a lot of sense, though Travis CI time is further elongated.

@jacobdevlin Sorry for the late reply. Was traveling and trying to build a basic prototype of sequence APIing during the last week. We will discuss to finalize that this weekend. I guess we can discuss about the details during the meeting. But here are some thoughts related to your comments above.

I think your concern that explicitly unrolled models have this issue of having to deal with sequences that are shorter than the unrolled length, especially in attention models and bidirectional models. But I do not understand how the Tensorflow way could resolve this. Based on my understanding of your description above, they explicitly unroll for several possible lengths (5, 10, 15, 25, etc.). But unless they do this for every possible sequence length, there is still cases where the actual sequence length does not match the unrolled length. Right? Are you talking about [this officien seq2seq example in tensorflow](https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/0.6.0/tutorials/seq2seq/index.html)? I will try to have a look at that before our discussion.

The prototype we come up is a hybrid imperative + symbolic solution with minimum modification to the existing MXNet internals. Basically it uses the Python side to explicitly schedule recurrence and the computation graph is instantiated only for one time step.
- We will support automatic unrolling, so if memory is enough, unrolling the symbolic graph for a few time steps would speed up the computation.
- While many of the existing RNN toolkits do recurrent scheduling at a _layer_ or _operator_ level, we do scheduling globally for the whole computation graph. We believe this is more efficient and in some way easier to crack within the current architecture of MXNet internals. This means
  - The whole network has to have the same recurrence sequence pattern (e.g. forward sweeping through the input sequence, backward sweeping, etc.). This is of course not true for the translation model you described above, because you have a bi-directional recurrence, which collapse into a single output, and then a forward RNN with attention to the original sequence. But this issue could resolved if we allow flexible composition or combination of RNN networks with different scheduling patterns. The actual API for composing networks is still open.
  - The layers with recurrence pattern does not need to be an _atomic_ operator (like `FullyConnected` or `Convolution`). It could be a sub computation graph that combines existing operators. As a result, it becomes very flexible to construct recurrent "operators" purely in Python by composing a subgraph using symbolic API. So for example, an LSTM cell, or the attention module -- a softmax that summarize the last 3 inputs for example -- could easily be defined in Python. 

I'll send the actual meeting time by tonight. We can discuss more details during the meeting. We appreciate a lot all your inputs and feedbacks!
Thanks! :)
I made a few comments. Overall this looks good. Thanks for your contribution.

Actually, I think you can use FeedForward model for this. There is no need to write a custom solver.
That being said, a guide on how to write custom solvers is also welcomed. Could you add a switch to allow using either FeedForward or custom solver?
You can write your custom data iterator. You can refer to io.DataIter and recordio.MXRecordIO
Another strategy is to modify iter_image_recordio.cc in src/io. There shouldn't be fundamental difficulty with supporting variable input size as long as the output images are croped to the same size.
Use model.fit(ctx=[mx.gpu(slow), mx.gpu(fast)], work_load_list=[1, 9]). Tune the numbers until it's not blocking.

OK, After reading the source I think I understand. I'll write a sort summary here for the records (in case there is someone as dumb as me..) and to get corrected if I am wrong before I close the issue.

Say you want to use a default initializer:
`default_initilializer = mx.init.Xavier(rnd_type="uniform", factor_type="in", magnitude=2.34)`

 for all your layers except for one, the layer defined as:

```
conv1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(
        data=input_data, kernel=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), num_filter=32,pad=(1,1),name="overriden")

```

*\* note that this layer has as name "overriden" and this we will used to do the regular expression pattern match in mx.init.Mixed**

For this layer you want to use a initializer of the form:

`override_initializer = mx.init.Normal(sigma=0.03)`

Then the final initializer to train the model should be: 
`mx.init.Mixed( patterns=[ 'overriden' , '.*' ] , initializers = [override_initializer , default_initilializer ] )`

This will initialize all layers with the default_initializer, except those that have "overriden" in the name that will be initialized with the override_initializer.
`

Try adding -DMSHADOW_USE_SSE=0 to ADD_CCFLAGS in config.mk and in mshadow/make/mshadow.mk:11, remove -msse3
You can do either. Python solution will be slower but it's not necessarily going to be the bottle neck.

You model was created using ctx=mx.gpu() and you are trying to load it with ctx=mx.cpu().
Only gpu version supports different stride. Load with gpu and you should be fine.
